column3: Meta DuEwa Jones
<font color='#008080'>-a, D-u capital E-w-a, J-o-n-e-s.</font>
Elizabeth Alexander
<font color='indigo'>Elizabeth Alexander. E-l-i-z-a-b-e-t-h, A-l-e-x-a-n-d-e-r.</font>
Meta DuEwa Jones

<font color='#008080'>All right. Wow. Elizabeth, I wanted to start out by asking you a question that it seems to me your work really bears to mind. And it's about the relationship between your work and</font>
<font color='#008080'>the African diaspora,</font>
<font color='#008080'>particularly one of the things that I noticed about your work is that you really kind of both embrace ideas about race, but also question the boundaries of it.</font>

<font color='#008080'>If you think about "West Indian Primer," where you're talking about both your Jamaican ancestry and then how it moves beyond that, or if you think about your poem for Nelson Mandela, where you start</font>

<font color='#008080'>talking about, you know, "I am a Black daughter," but in a way that connects to the South African president, and in an interesting way. Could you talk about the relationship between your work and a</font>
<font color='#008080'>diasporic context?</font>
Elizabeth Alexander

<font color='indigo'>Well, that reading that you just gave of that line, "I am a Black daughter," that break-- It seems to me, and I'm just now thinking about this, echoes Gwendolyn Brooks' great poem</font>

<font color='indigo'>where she talks about "I am a Black," "I am one of the Blacks," where she feels that to be called merely African American is limiting and almost in a way euphemistic. That it skips over an</font>
<font color='indigo'>understanding of how we are all connected to each other, across the globe.</font>

<font color='indigo'>Sometimes in our actual histories, in the case of the Jamaican grandfather there's a lot of personal history in my poems as you know, or in newer poems. My husband is from Eritrea, so now I have a</font>

<font color='indigo'>whole East African connection going on. But in a way, I think what we learn from those real histories is how complicated and sometimes nostalgic and sometimes full of fantasy, the idea of Africa is</font>
<font color='indigo'>for us.</font>

<font color='indigo'>You know, and I think that as African Americans, we have always tried to connect to that idea, because so much has been cut off and interrupted. But at the same time, it's a fantasy,</font>

<font color='indigo'>though I think it is a heartfelt and beautiful fantasy that has led many of us, myself included, to reading and learning and reaching out and exploration and trying to theorize in very personal terms:</font>
<font color='indigo'>What does it mean to be African people in this diaspora all across the world?</font>

<font color='indigo'>I think also one of the beautiful realities of the United States, and for me of growing up in Washington, DC, is that you met Black people from all over the world. And that's something I touch on as</font>
<font color='indigo'>well, something that was very important to my own African American grandmother growing up in Washington, DC.</font>

<font color='indigo'>She would go and sit on the steps of embassies, because it let her imagine the world. And so that was a fortunate thing to grow up with: just that sense that we are, we are a multi-people.</font>
Meta DuEwa Jones

<font color='#008080'>It's-- I love hearing you talk about that. Because in that poem that, where you actually invoke your grandmother sitting on the steps of embassy row, you have the line where you talk</font>

<font color='#008080'>about what is a princess like in 'Feminist Poem Number One', what is, uh, what your grandmother would call and say to her-- her international friends, I am an American Negro, right, and what is an</font>
<font color='#008080'>American Negro princess? And so in some ways, I think that hearing you talk about that--</font>

<font color='#008080'>and then in that same poem you actually refer to your husband and then talk about, you know, as an Abyssinian. And so its interesting how, within the context of one poem, both in terms of gender</font>
<font color='#008080'>relationships, in terms of how that intersects our ideas about race and our ideas about kind of connections to Africa, that all gets kind of wrapped up into that,</font>

<font color='#008080'>as well as class, right? Because anytime you kind of invoke these ideas about the princesses, it's the sense of the grandmother who wants to travel to see the world and you have traveled to see the</font>
<font color='#008080'>world, right. Within the context of the line, for the poem the husband that takes you to the airport for a passport, which means of course that you're--</font>
Elizabeth Alexander
<font color='indigo'>Going somewhere.</font>
Meta DuEwa Jones

<font color='#008080'>You're going somewhere, right, and eventually coming back. And so I think that's really a useful way to think about it. But even domestically, I find that your work covers so many</font>
<font color='#008080'>different kinds of Black artists and authors and photographers and athletes from Mohammed Ali to James Van Der Zee to Paul Robeson to Romero Bearden,</font>

<font color='#008080'>and I'm wondering if you'd be interested in talking a little bit about, about myth, right, and Black mythic figures and major historical figures that seem to occur in your work. And I note that my</font>

<font color='#008080'>list-- at this moment I'm using Black male figures because we started, um I moved in a bit of a different direction, but even your, in, Nat Turner poem. Right? So if, would you comment on that?</font>
Elizabeth Alexander

<font color='indigo'>Well yeah, I mean, I think our history, our culture is so rich, it's so under explored, it's so distortedly imagined, that it just has always seemed to me that that is an infinite</font>

<font color='indigo'>mother lode for poetry. I think in some ways, what that speaks to biographically is that I spent a lot of time in school and in universities, although when I think about the reading, that gave me my</font>
<font color='indigo'>information, very often, it was actually autodidactic study,</font>

<font color='indigo'>it was not always what I was learning in school. But nonetheless, that context, that idea of reading to know, reading as experience that is deeply, deeply felt, and taken in reading as being-- and</font>
<font color='indigo'>learning, as somehow on a, an equivalent plane to the things that you know from living your life without books.</font>

<font color='indigo'>You know, to those of us for whom culture is that important, I think it's important to assert that it's lived life, it's real experience. So calling all of that in, being a scholar of African American</font>

<font color='indigo'>culture, you know, it's what I teach, it's what I've been thinking about for a long time, I find that poems are a great place to work with that. That said, this whole idea of myth, you know, I, the</font>
<font color='indigo'>word Abyssinian,</font>
Meta DuEwa Jones
<font color='#008080'>Yes.</font>
Elizabeth Alexander
<font color='indigo'>You know that that's, that's an old timey word,</font>
Meta DuEwa Jones
<font color='#008080'>Right, of course it is! Exactly.</font>
Elizabeth Alexander
<font color='indigo'>That's not what you call people today, from Eritrea.</font>
Meta DuEwa Jones
<font color='#008080'>No, not at all! Of course, of course, I do know that, so.</font>
Elizabeth Alexander

<font color='indigo'>So you know, that whole, you know that to me-- yeah, I think where did it come from? That was a magical word. One of those sort of elsewhere words, one of those elsewhere Black</font>
<font color='indigo'>people words, that has appealed to me from God knows what sources from as long as I can remember.</font>
Meta DuEwa Jones

<font color='#008080'>Yes, yes. Thank you so much. Well, it's interesting hearing you talk about kind of-- in that context, you being a scholar of African American culture, and a teacher in points being</font>

<font color='#008080'>the space where you're able to kind of explore this mother lode, because I'd actually like to talk a little bit about your newest work, 'The Black Interior'. And one of the things, you know, first off</font>
<font color='#008080'>that is different, right, is that it's a collection of essays obviously, unlike your previous three books before that.</font>

<font color='#008080'>And it strikes me that it is at once both scholarly, but also attempting to speak to a larger community that is not just dealing with issues of books, right, we have essays in there, one on Julia</font>

<font color='#008080'>Cooper, of course, so that's definitely in the kind of intellectual or readerly tradition. But you have an essay on Denzel Washington, right? You have an essay on Rodney King. You have an essay, my</font>
goodness on Jet, right?

<font color='#008080'>"Notes Toward a Notion of Race-Pride." And so there's a way in which I really see your work as working with both, kind of, the African American scholarly tradition in terms of literary culture, but</font>

<font color='#008080'>also and I think in important ways, more broadly, popular culture, right, in ways that I think, are useful for students, right? Because I know that, that you also teach. Could you talk about kind of</font>
the role that you see Black Interior playing in the trajectory of your work as a writer? And--
Elizabeth Alexander

<font color='indigo'>Yeah. Well, I mean, I think one of the things, you know, when you're taught close reading as a method in graduate study and undergraduate study English classes, it should be</font>
<font color='indigo'>applicable to anything that constitutes a text.</font>
Meta DuEwa Jones
<font color='#008080'>Yes.</font>
Elizabeth Alexander

<font color='indigo'>So there was actually a wonderful article by Stanley Fish, your UIC colleague, at, in the New York Times where he was-- had his students do close readings of a speech by Bush, a</font>
<font color='indigo'>speech by Kerry. And he talked about repetition, assonance, all the, the-- what we think of as poetic devices of how people do or don't get their message across.</font>

<font color='indigo'>How language works on us. So I think those tools, we should be able to turn them anyplace. And while I do think that there are all kinds of things that you can say about, you know, "poetry is not</font>
Jet magazine." But, at the same time, how does our culture manifest itself? How does it live in people who don't necessarily call themselves professional artists? And how do a lot of the issues
<font color='indigo'>that are of importance in our poetry and in our popular culture cross back and forth.</font>

<font color='indigo'>I'm very interested in that. The book, as you know, was a long time coming, and in many ways that long time is a testimony to the challenges of finding a prose voice. You know, when an academic, a</font>

<font color='indigo'>more conventionally academic voice didn't feel like a jacket that fit. And at the same time, I wanted to bring in what I know as an artist, how I look at the world as an artist,</font>

<font color='indigo'>and I wanted to operate in a tradition of belles lettres that is exemplified by people like June Jordan, who's a very, very important figure to me, and who's an incredibly important essayist, and I</font>
<font color='indigo'>believe, has published more essays than any Black woman in history.</font>
Meta DuEwa Jones
<font color='#008080'>Yes.</font>
Elizabeth Alexander
<font color='indigo'>I'm pretty sure that that's, that that's true.</font>
Elizabeth Alexander

<font color='indigo'>And so what does it mean to, in the way that I love, to listen to a smart person with a wide field of reference, hold forth. Felicitously. I wanted to be that person in writing.</font>
Meta DuEwa Jones
<font color='#008080'>Yes.</font>

<font color='#008080'>And I think that actually also within Blackness, we, we have so many great raconteurs, we have so many oral geniuses who can hold forth, in a way that is just amazing. And so I think that somehow also</font>

<font color='#008080'>those patterns of address and argument were somehow underneath and in there as well. But finding that voice was challenging. And now that the book is out there, you know, my, my wish and my hope is</font>
<font color='#008080'>that it find its readers. And I think that's a slow process too.</font>
Meta DuEwa Jones
<font color='#008080'>Oh, absolutely, absolutely.</font>
Elizabeth Alexander
<font color='indigo'>Yeah, but that's okay.</font>
Meta DuEwa Jones

<font color='#008080'>Right. Well, I-- well in, within the context of the readership or audience of 'Black Interior', I think different people will come to the book with different needs and expectations.</font>
<font color='#008080'>And so the nice thing about kind of the aspect of it being a work that looks at different aspects of Black culture in very diverse ways.</font>

<font color='#008080'>And also, I think, using a language that is not an academic straightjacket, you know, in terms of, as a scholar of African American literature, the tradition, in terms of the scholarly tradition,</font>
<font color='#008080'>there's certain expectations about language and kind of heightened language, or what is recognized or thought of as theoretical language.</font>

<font color='#008080'>And yet, I find in 'The Black Interior', if you think, for example of your essay on Michael Harper, who I know has been an influence on you, that there is a way in which you, you use insightful close</font>
<font color='#008080'>readings, right, of some of his, of his poems from 'Dear John, Dear Coltrane', and poems, on Bessie Smith, for example,</font>

<font color='#008080'>but not terminology, that someone who has not taken, you know, American poetry 101 at Yale University would not be able to understand. And I think that's really important terms of thinking about kind</font>
<font color='#008080'>of the artist and her relationship to community, right, and to audience in really, really useful ways.</font>
Elizabeth Alexander

<font color='indigo'>And I think also there's something interesting, I haven't, I'm just thinking of it this very moment, but something interesting about hierarchy and apprenticeship, in the ways that</font>

<font color='indigo'>people are quoted, other experts and colleagues are quoted in the essays. But my dad read some of them in an earlier phase, he said, Why do you have to quote 10 people to say what you're trying to</font>
<font color='indigo'>say? Just say what you're trying to say, and-- you're a grown up.</font>
Meta DuEwa Jones
<font color='#008080'>Right.</font>
Elizabeth Alexander

<font color='indigo'>Say what you're trying to say. But of course, you know, in, in academic writing, you have to quote 10 other people, who said what you said first, in order to say what you have to</font>

<font color='indigo'>say. And yet I do think that there is something within our oral communities about earning the right to speak, and about moving through ancestral wisdom and knowledge in order to have your moment to</font>
<font color='indigo'>hold forth. So I think that there are different ways of sort of moving through those channels, to your moment in the sun.</font>
Meta DuEwa Jones

<font color='#008080'>Oh, I'm glad you mentioned that. Because when you think about the kind of oral communities or oral culture in the way that it's associated with Black culture as an oral culture.</font>
<font color='#008080'>Though, of course, in terms of scholarship, people are questioning that as a too easy identification.</font>

<font color='#008080'>But one thing I noticed in your poetry is that, and you mentioned this at a conference at Yale a few years ago, where you're talking about kind of giving voice to Black female figures within our</font>
<font color='#008080'>history, that you seem to not be able to find in the historical record, a record of their voice, right? And so,</font>

<font color='#008080'>you have the poem "Yolande Speaks" right, in which you think about all the literature about Dubois, and even though you know, Gerald Horne has done a wonderful biography of Shirley Dubois, that</font>

<font color='#008080'>Dubois' daughter, right, his only daughter, we don't hear her voice as much in the historical record. And there's a there's a way in which, you know, poems such as that where you have her not only</font>
<font color='#008080'>have a voice but a perspective, right?</font>

<font color='#008080'>She's like: "I've laughed/ at my father's gloves// and spats," which both humanizes him but also gives her kind of a sense of distance from him to kind of have a perspective on, on him.  Or your, your</font>
first book of poetry, The Venus Hottentot, which, which opens with, you know-- although it opens with Cuvier by the time we get to Saartjie Bartman's voice, right, you have her being
<font color='#008080'>insistently multilingual, right? I speak English, I speak French, I speak Dutch and I even speak "languages Monsieur Cuvier/ will never know have names".</font>
<font color='#008080'>There's a way in which I think that your work really does speak to the need for an awareness of this kind of orality as an aspect of Black culture without simplifying it.</font>
Elizabeth Alexander

<font color='indigo'>Mm hmm. Yes. And I think also with that moment in Venus Hottentot, the idea that we always are trying-- we always know more than we manifest. And that really interests me, both</font>
<font color='indigo'>with myself, in my own continual-- I think it's a lifelong process of coming to voice, you know. You get there, okay, but then you keep moving forward,</font>

<font color='indigo'>and really trying to process and distill all the knowledge and all the wisdom. But we always know more than we manifest. And she is a great exemplar of that. And I think that's a very interesting</font>
<font color='indigo'>secret weapon.</font>
Meta DuEwa Jones
<font color='#008080'>Yes, yes. Absolutely.</font>
Elizabeth Alexander
<font color='indigo'>That we need to think about.</font>
Meta DuEwa Jones
<font color='#008080'>Absolutely. I wanna actually shift to talk about the visuals, [inaudible] by talking about the oral. And I brought with me, my beloved copies of,</font>
Meta DuEwa Jones

<font color='#008080'>The babies! I'm sure they're your babies, but my copies of them. My duplicates, and one thing that really strikes me is your-- the, and I don't know what degree of control you have</font>
Elizabeth Alexander
<font color='indigo'>The babies.</font>

<font color='indigo'>over this, whether it's your editors' choices, or whether you're involved in the selection of this, but the covers of your books, right, and the beautiful artwork that has-- and Black artwork, you</font>
<font color='indigo'>know, in particular--</font>
<font color='indigo'>that has been a part of the process of your books. And I wondered if you could talk--</font>
Elizabeth Alexander
<font color='indigo'>Yes, absolutely.</font>
Meta DuEwa Jones
<font color='#008080'>a bit about each one. And I'm missing, I didn't bring with me, it's back in my office, the original, right, copy of The Venus Hott--</font>
Elizabeth Alexander
<font color='indigo'>But we can talk about that.</font>
Meta DuEwa Jones

<font color='#008080'>But if we could, I thought it would be really useful. Because so much of your work-- Although I've made that kind of oral comment, there's also a way in which you have so many poems</font>

<font color='#008080'>that really deal with the visual image, right, and the concrete visual image, with visual artists, Bearden, Monet and so forth. The photographers. But, but there's a way in which I sense your work,</font>
and certainly in essays in The Black Interior, where you talk about how do Blacks relate to kind of the distortion of images of ourselves,
<font color='#008080'>and culture and-- without feeling the imperative to just only create positive images.</font>
Elizabeth Alexander
<font color='indigo'>That's right.</font>
Meta DuEwa Jones
<font color='#008080'>So if you could just talk about your book covers and visuality in general, I'd appreciate it.</font>
Elizabeth Alexander
Well, I've been very aggressive about controlling that. And with the first cover of The Venus Hottentot, that was University of Virginia press, many many years ago. And the
<font color='indigo'>first cover that was-- I thought, let's see what they come up with.</font>

<font color='indigo'>As much as art is so important to me and as much as beautiful books are important to me. And what they came up with was a baby aspirin colored cover with scallop shells alluding as best I could see to</font>
<font color='indigo'>Venus de Milo rising up out of the sea. And I thought, okay, so if after reading that poem, that is the title poem of that book, all-- it sort of proves the thesis.</font>
Meta DuEwa Jones
<font color='#008080'>Yes.</font>
Elizabeth Alexander
<font color='indigo'>You know, and what you see and what you imagine, is Venus de Milo coming out of the sea, and that the color in which you cast these poems is baby aspirin, pinky-peach.</font>
Meta DuEwa Jones
<font color='#008080'>Yes, yeah.</font>
Elizabeth Alexander
<font color='indigo'>I got to take control of this. We, you can't sort of negotiate with that. You can't work with that. That's too far out.</font>
Meta DuEwa Jones
<font color='#008080'>That's so true.</font>
Elizabeth Alexander

<font color='indigo'>So the the painting that I chose was a painting by Charles Alston, who's my great uncle, my mother's uncle, and it's called ballet dancer, and it's a picture of a Black woman--</font>

<font color='indigo'>too bad the picture couldn't have been in color because you can see it's sort of yellows and olives. She looks a bit whiter colored than she actually is in the reproduction, but she has a kind of</font>
<font color='indigo'>physical composure.</font>

<font color='indigo'>That seemed to me to be very important as that relates to The Venus Hottentot. What does it mean to be that woman who's-- she's in leotards, her body is outlined and exposed, but yet, even though you</font>
<font color='indigo'>are being watched, your inner life is your own. That was what I thought was in that implacable face in that, in that painting.</font>

<font color='indigo'>And so ever after, you know I just, it was with 'Body of Life' which is Tia Chucha press, they were very excited to have me find my own cover, and this is by a great painter, who's a friend of mine,</font>

<font color='indigo'>Kerry James Marshall. And there's a lot of romantic dynamics in this book and this painting is called "Could This be Love". And just a fabulous painting with so many small details that you can just</font>
<font color='indigo'>about make up:</font>

<font color='indigo'>the calendar stained with her menstrual blood, the sculpture, the Africanesque sculpture in the background echoing her form. All that Kerry James Marshall does with the black black that is not the</font>

<font color='indigo'>color of anyone, but is a color of sort of mythos in a way. The songs in the background, he's saying, "What a woman, what a woman, what a woman." So there's just a lot you know, the, the Vodoun heart</font>
<font color='indigo'>in there.</font>

<font color='indigo'>So much going on, a very talky painting in a way that I think, communicates nicely with the paintings inside. Then in 'Antebellum Dream Book' again, the first cover that was given to me-- I said</font>
<font color='indigo'>again, I'm at a new press, a press that I love, let me see what they do. And it was a picture of, you know I said it looked like the cover to Sounder.</font>
Meta DuEwa Jones
<font color='#008080'>Oh my goodness.</font>
Elizabeth Alexander

<font color='indigo'>There's a Black girl on a porch, screen door, basket of produce. And I said, so how do you read that book and make that cover? Again, it speaks to me to-- how are they seeing us?</font>
Meta DuEwa Jones
<font color='#008080'>Yes, absolutely.</font>
Elizabeth Alexander

<font color='indigo'>How, with, with the book in-- and so I said, can't work with this, we got to just start all over again. And this painting is Bob Thompson's "The Garden of Music," which I just</font>
<font color='indigo'>adore. And because there are dream poems in the book, I felt that there was a very dreamlike quality, a surreal quality to these wonderful purple people.</font>

<font color='indigo'>And, you know, that, that it was a dreamscape in a way that I thought worked with the books, the poems inside. And then with Black Interior, we've spoken at the conference, Sonia Sanchez mentioned,</font>
<font color='indigo'>the great Elizabeth Catlett. And this image is called "The Black Woman Speaks".</font>
Meta DuEwa Jones
<font color='#008080'>So appropriate.</font>
Elizabeth Alexander

<font color='indigo'>You know, and there it is. And as I talk about in the book, what you can't see on the picture, on the side, there is a sort of a spiral that's inscribed on her temple, if you were</font>

<font color='indigo'>to have a side view. And you know, the spiral is a symbol of infinity, and it seems to me that that it also suggests, it almost-- as though it's a drawing of what's inside the Black woman's head.</font>
Meta DuEwa Jones
<font color='#008080'>Yes, yes.</font>
Elizabeth Alexander
<font color='indigo'>An infinite, infinite spiral. And Catlett made this work in about 1970, when she herself was a very, very mature artist, mother of grown children. Which connects with my</font>

<font color='indigo'>conversation of Gwendolyn Brooks, at the same point more or less in her life. A very senior woman, a very acclaimed artist, nonetheless subject to change, responsive to the times.</font>
Meta DuEwa Jones
<font color='#008080'>Willing to evolve.</font>
Elizabeth Alexander

<font color='indigo'>Willing to evolve. And I think that, that was-- in addition to just that it's, it's a ravishing piece of work, it's a beautiful, beautiful sculpture. And it's it's also a nice</font>

<font color='indigo'>picture of a sculpture, which is hard to do sometimes. But to me, you know, I'm interested in artists' careers over time, you know, want to be in it for the long haul. And so and that's why it's so</font>
<font color='indigo'>fortunate to be here with people like Sonia and Lucille.</font>
Meta DuEwa Jones
<font color='#008080'>Because you see that long, tradition. Long tradition.</font>
Elizabeth Alexander
<font color='indigo'>Long, and you know, and that these are people who have also-- I have small children, these are people who have raised children, who have made a life in the arts.</font>
Meta DuEwa Jones
<font color='#008080'>And mothers, and wives, and partners and all of these things and still been artists,</font>
Elizabeth Alexander
<font color='indigo'>Yes.</font>
Meta DuEwa Jones
<font color='#008080'>And scholars, and in so many ways and theorists of Black culture, right. And so.</font>
Elizabeth Alexander
<font color='indigo'>Yes, yes, yes. And so that's, those are the women that give me power, you know.</font>
Meta DuEwa Jones

<font color='#008080'>Me as well. I can definitely identify with that. Thank you so much for that. I want to ask a more just simply basic question, since I've been-- How do you know when you are ready to</font>
<font color='#008080'>start or finish a poem?</font>
Elizabeth Alexander

<font color='indigo'>Ooh. Well at this conference I have felt really ready to start a lot of poems. I think that being around poetry and being around people who make poetry makes new poems happen, you</font>

<font color='indigo'>know. It's like this incredible, biodynamic thing that, that happens, you just sort of-- you take a word, you take a line, you take a sort of a modal imprint, and the poems are ready to come.</font>

<font color='indigo'>And then for me, as for all of us, there's always the question of time, and where to find-- you know, I love that Lucille Clifton, when she was talking about what it was to have four children in</font>
<font color='indigo'>diapers at the same time. And she said to the audience, you think you're busy?</font>
Meta DuEwa Jones
<font color='#008080'>Right. Right. Absolutely.</font>
Elizabeth Alexander

<font color='indigo'>And she has spoken about actually how the ideal circumstances for her to write poetry became domestic chaos.  Because that's what it was. You know, that if you know, she says,</font>

<font color='indigo'>one-- you're at the kitchen table, and one child's got the measles and the other child's got the homework and that everything is going on. Nonetheless, you somehow make that space. And I am working to</font>

<font color='indigo'>do that as I think whether or not we have children we're always, in the midst of our lives, we all have to make a living. No poet is supporting him or herself solely by the word.</font>

<font color='indigo'>So you're trying to make that bubble, or develop the habit that says, at least in my bag, the notebook is always there. Although, because driving ends up sometimes to be the only free time there is.</font>

<font color='indigo'>Can't quite write the things down as well, you know, on the road, as well as you would like to. So it's that feeling though, which I'm having now which I'm having after this conference of being full</font>
<font color='indigo'>up.</font>

<font color='indigo'>And then you know, then there's process, process, process. But then the ready to be done with it is a tricky thing as well. I was speaking with some students recently about how you sort of go as far</font>

<font color='indigo'>as you can, and then you leave it and come back to it after it's had time to sit. And then you can more clearly see, okay, was I just tired? Was I just out of ideas? Or maybe this really is done.</font>

<font color='indigo'>Or maybe now I can see what the final tweak is. And I have poems that have remained in folders for years and years and years and years, snippets for years, that then you find, okay, this is how I can</font>
<font color='indigo'>use this. This is how I can complete this.</font>
Meta DuEwa Jones
<font color='#008080'>Do you revise your work alot?</font>
Elizabeth Alexander
